title: An advertisement for Support
body:
>**You -- yes you reading this post -- should try out SUPPORT!**
>
>You'll get the chance to be 2-5 levels behind most of the players in the game, on 2/3 of their budget, with 5050 gold of mandatory purchases before you can choose what to build.. ..and in exchange you'll get to help your allies make some really sweet plays!

Riot, I love playing support, but there is some baseline amount of agency I need in a normal game to make the role worth playing, and it just ain't there right now.

Edit since people weren't noticing the link: Here's why I love playing support: http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/me7PRvfg-an-advertisement-for-support?comment=0000

They need to fix XP issues on support before anything else.

Most people will not play support simply because it sucks being 2-3 levels behind a 0/4/0 Sion top with mediocre farm when you're 0/0/7 and doing amazing. It makes carrying your game even more difficult than it already was.

I made it to Gold again as a support main this year, and I don't mind having to stretch my coin. I wish I didn't have to. It's sucky that I have the smallest income with must-buy items like Sightstone, but I can work with it. What really makes me annoyed is the XP issues. Just start with that Riot, please.

Another thing I want them to add is more detailed stats that show a support's contribution post game. I want to see how much damage I buffed through spells and items and how much damage I absorbed through shields for instance. This would be so helpful for people who want to know what they should work on for next game as well.

Give us those two things Riot, or at least try to work towards them! It doesn't look like we will get a support update anytime soon, but I want them to to start making minor changes.
Fully agree about the stat thing. A bit of e-penis measuring won't hurt the appeal of the role, on top of everything else you mentioned.

# Supporting is like directing an artillery barrage.

If you pick the right target and time, you blow the enemy to smithereens. Sure, you didn't actually fire the weapon, but that doesn't matter. **People don't praise the brilliance of artillery operators, they praise the brilliance of the general.**

As someone who's played quite a bit of every role, there is nothing so intensely invigorating as playing support, *if you're on the same page as your adc.* You land your CC on the right target, call down the artillery, and the target blows up. **You may not have done the right-clicking, but you were the reason that damage happened.**

The only problem I see with the old support mastery is: if it's strong enough, it might be desirable to take it on more than just supports, so you can get bonus xp if one of your other lanes snowballs, which means your whole team can snowball off that one person -- it doesn't just help the team that's behind.

I think attaching the effect to an item sidesteps that problem because laners wouldn't want to invest gold into something that doesn't give as many combat stats.

Or you could attach the effect to XP for assists if you kill someone higher leveled than you, or something like that.

Do you like being blamed for lack of vision despite you being the only person putting down wards?  

Do you like to watch your ADC miss CS, get hit by CC, and die for no reason while you sit there helplessly?   

Do you like to roam to other lanes only for your ADC to 1v2 10 seconds later and blame you for leaving?  

Do you like to be abandoned and sacrificed at any given point for no reason and then get blamed for dying?  

Do you like being one of the only roles to be forced into buying certain items by your teammates on a fraction of the gold?  

If you answered yes to any of these questions, then oh boy do I have a Role for you!

I think it could happen (well, the gold. There will always need to be some power level dip for sharing a lane, I think) but would require some pretty drastic changes. That work could be put into several other class reworks, which I think would be a better use of time and resources.

But in the meantime, support needs a little something, because right now the role feels terrible.

This is a pretty good way to put it. When undecided players look at which position to play, they evaluate the pros and cons of each one, what they get to do that's unique, what the tradeoffs are, etc. In the case of supports, though, there are far too many cons: focusing on assisting allies is itself pretty divisive, as it's considered a positive by only a subset of players (which is fine), and disliked by many others, but adding to that is a laundry list of gameplay issues that weigh Support down. Not only do supports often have less gold, experience and overall freedom than most other champions, it's also mandatory to have a support every game, which causes even support mains to eventually burn out. By contrast, marksmen, the only other mandatory class, get priority for gold income and team assistance, and itemize to feel like the most powerful champions in the game.

I think the issue with the support position is that its implementation is sort of backwards: because its appeal is so niche (few people want to sacrifice personal glory for team synergy, and supports across all games tend to be the least popular class), the class and the position both need to essentially have every other concession made for them in order to be popular: at the very least, they should be running on equal gold and experience with their allies, and even if they somehow had the highest gold and XP income, they'd still be niche. They deserve access to items that make them feel powerful at what they do, and focus on their champion's own unique contribution to their team. Even in terms of recognition, there's work to be done, and any champion who assisted in a massive play or an ace deserves recognition on the same level as a kill streak. Instead, supports are saddled with some of the game's largest and most severe set of restrictions, and don't feel valued nearly enough for the tremendous contributions they make to their team.

As for solutions, at this point I think it might be beneficial to supports if Riot removed the Sightstone line: the item is boring, none of its upgrades feel worth buying, yet the item is also mandatory. Supports are not only required to spend an item slot for an effect everyone can already access via trinkets, the very existence of Sightstone forces supports to shoulder the burden of vision more than any other class, which is neither fun nor functional. Without it, supports would have 800 gold and an item slot off of their mandatory build, and remaining items and trinkets could then be buffed as necessary for teams to have the same overall amount of vision and counter-vision. A change like that alone wouldn't solve all the issues with Support, but could go a long way in making them feel more fun.

The flip side is that removing SS means supports can't sweep and ward at the same time, which gives them even less agency. Probably not worth it for the meager 800g they gain.

That said, if it were paired with other changes, like ramping up how much gold the income items give, I could certainly see it being beneficial.

Also, support is my favorite role, but it's not exactly because I like "assisting" allies. See the comment I linked in the OP for more on that.

> [{quoted}](name=Hyrum Graff,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=me7PRvfg,comment-id=00100000,timestamp=2016-11-04T15:53:13.668+0000)
>
> The flip side is that removing SS means supports can't sweep and ward at the same time, which gives them even less agency.

I don't think sweeping and warding simultaneously can really qualify as "agency" when you're forced to do it, especially when doing so comes at a large overall cost in gold and experience due to being out of lane. If supports could only either ward or sweep, they'd have more time to do things that would not involve laying down the vision everybody's supposed to partipate equally in, and could thereby have more agency overall, as they'd get to be closer to where the action is. Having supports dip into vision more than anyone else has never really turned out well for them, and has limited both their itemization and gameplay choices. Prior to Preseason 6, removing Sightstone would have been horrible, because supports would have been forced to load up on wards 24/7, but now that stealth wards aren't purchaseable, there's no "alternative option" for supports to fall back onto, besides maybe Tracker's Knife, which means there wouldn't really be a way for them to be forced to buy a new mandatory vision item, or to do more vision things than anyone else.

As for the game's gold income items, while I think they're ultimately a crutch that should be solved through changes to duo+ laning income, I agree that they should give more gold, though they should likely also have tighter restrictions on their gold generation to avoid being used by solo laners. Having Favor work purely on ally minion kills, and Tribute only activate when an ally is nearby, for example, could achieve that. I also think that their gold generation should be the same across all tiers of each item, which would put less pressure on supports to dump all of their gold into upgrading them early.

> [{quoted}](name=Teridax68,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=me7PRvfg,comment-id=001000000000,timestamp=2016-11-04T22:28:34.877+0000)

> I don't think sweeping and warding simultaneously can really qualify as "agency" when you're forced to do it, especially when doing so comes at a large overall cost in gold and experience due to being out of lane.

That's a reasonable argument. Controlling vision does dictate which objectives your team and theirs are able to take, so I think that is something.

That said, it's also easy for a support alone to be caught out while sweeping or warding, and when you need another teammate to come with you to ward/sweep, your agency is now gone anyway.

>If supports could only either ward or sweep, they'd have more time to do things that would not involve laying down the vision everybody's supposed to partipate equally in, and could thereby have more agency overall, as they'd get to be closer to where the action is. Having supports dip into vision more than anyone else has never really turned out well for them, and has limited both their itemization and gameplay choices. Prior to Preseason 6, removing Sightstone would have been horrible, because supports would have been forced to load up on wards 24/7, but now that stealth wards aren't purchaseable, there's no "alternative option" for supports to fall back onto, besides maybe Tracker's Knife, which means there wouldn't really be a way for them to be forced to buy a new mandatory vision item, or to do more vision things than anyone else.

Also reasonable. I suspect Tracker's would need to go as well, lest junglers become the new supports.

> As for the game's gold income items, while I think they're ultimately a crutch that should be solved through changes to duo+ laning income, I agree that they should give more gold, though they should likely also have tighter restrictions on their gold generation to avoid being used by solo laners. Having Favor work purely on ally minion kills, and Tribute only activate when an ally is nearby, for example, could achieve that. I also think that their gold generation should be the same across all tiers of each item, which would put less pressure on supports to dump all of their gold into upgrading them early.

It would be really interesting to add in that version of favor as a part of the base game. Something like, "When a player kills a minion, 40% of the gold earned by that player is split evenly among nearby allies." Then remove gold gen items (or just replace the gold gen part with something else).

> [{quoted}](name=Hyrum Graff,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=me7PRvfg,comment-id=0010000000000000,timestamp=2016-11-05T02:26:46.775+0000)
> 
> That said, it's also easy for a support alone to be caught out while sweeping or warding, and when you need another teammate to come with you to ward/sweep, your agency is now gone anyway.

I completely agree with this, which is one of the reasons why I think it's completely backwards for supports to be the ones to go ward/counter-ward more than anyone else. Supports are the least independent class around by design; requiring them to go alone into risky territory more than anyone else might create some interesting tension, but doesn't feel fair either.

> [{quoted}](name=Hyrum Graff,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=me7PRvfg,comment-id=0010000000000000,timestamp=2016-11-05T02:26:46.775+0000)
> 
> Also reasonable. I suspect Tracker's would need to go as well, lest junglers become the new supports.

I agree with this too, Tracker's Knife right now is the fallback option for junglers who don't really want either Smite upgrade, and is niche to the point of having a pick rate consistently below 0.2%. I don't think Sightstone's removal would drastically increase its pick rate, but removing Tracker's Knife would still be an improvement. Generally, I think it might be better for vision to not be increased through any itemization means other than trinkets, since that's when there's the risk of players going for boring-but-essential gold investments.

I agree, and I think it might better for the game if it evolved towards equal sharing of gold from all takedowns, both against minions and champions. The current problem is that duo+ laning is designed to be bad without a support, because unbalanced lanes, e.g. 2v1s and the like, are absolutely horrible for both sides. The outnumbered side doesn't have that many options, and the side outnumbering them has to compete for lessened individual rewards. For duo lanes to naturally give better gold and experience, the game needs to solve the problem of stacked lanes, which would hopefully also extend to answering cheesy deathball strats.

Right now, almost every support should buy locket immediately after the other mandatory purchases (and occasionally I'll get aegis before SS). The only times when you can buy a different item first are:

1. On karma, because she gets SO much benefit out of CDR. But you should get it ASAP after you hit 25-35% cdr.
2. If you're playing against a full AD team comp (something like Irelia / Zed / Yi / Lucian / Janna). If they have even a little hybrid damage or AP tank, like Jayce, Gnar, Leona, Naut, Maokai, Malphite, etc, this doesn't apply.
3. If the enemy has a fed AP splitpush threat or your team has no concept of wave control, you can get banner instead.

Locket's aura (and to a lesser extent, shield) gives such strong, reliable power that anything else puts you at a significant disadvantage. Locket gives all nearby teammates 15 MR. Before penetration, that's 15% magic damage reduction, (more like 10% after all's said and done) permanently. Compare to exhaust, which reduces a champion's damage by 40%. Would you spend 2500 gold if Locket were described as "A permanent semi-exhaust on all nearby enemy AP champions"?

The problem with is that, despite Locket being blatantly OP, it's really hard to feel the impact of its power, because AP champions are balanced around the assumption that the enemy team will have one. So the scenario ends up being -- when your team has a locket, it's business as usual, and then when you don't have a locket it's HOLY DICKS HOW DID LB JUST KILL ME WITH TWO ABILITIES.
